abstract.p: Monica Drinane letter comments on Patrick T Murphy's August 11 Op-Ed article, which said there has been decline in child abuse cases nationwide since passage of welfare reform law in 1996 (S)

Re ''A Trap of Welfare and Child Abuse,'' by Patrick T. Murphy (Op-Ed, Aug. 11):

Teenage pregnancy remains a significant problem in this country, and according to Planned Parenthood, teenage pregnancy increased in New York City by 7 percent over the last four years. The reality is that welfare reform does not deter teenage pregnancy but that access to education, good health care and training in marketable job skills does.

Typically from our poorest neighborhoods, teenage mothers are less likely to complete high school, go to college or get married. Most telling, their children are more likely to become teenage parents themselves. A recent decline in teenage birth rates nationwide does not negate the fact that teenage pregnancy is still a troubling issue for our society.
The writer is attorney in charge of the juvenile rights division, Legal Aid Society.
